newsitem.title: HONG KONG: HK anti-graft police arrest six in newspaper probe.
newsitem.headline: HK anti-graft police arrest six in newspaper probe.

text.p: Anti-corruption police raided one of Hong Kong's two metropolitan English-language newspapers on Wednesday and arrested six people in a fraudulent-circulation probe, an official statement said.

The Independent Commission Against Corruption (ICAC) said those detained were four current employees of Hong Kong Standard Newspapers Ltd, and two former employees. All were being released on bail later.
The agency emphasised that the daily and Sunday newspapers' editorial operations were not subject of the investigation, which focused on printing, circulation, sales and marketing activities.

It cited allegations that up to 23,000 copies a day had been printed as surplus and sold as waste, to "deceive a British-based circulation audit company and local advertising clients of both newspapers."

No comment was available immediately at Hong Kong Standard Newspapers, publisher of the Hong Kong Standard and the Hong Kong Sunday Standard. Calls to company secretary Kwok Siu-man and editors were not returned.
The company is a wholly-owned subsidiary of Sing Tao Holdings Ltd, a major media group whose Chinese-language Sing Tao daily circulates internationally including Britain and North America.
The parent firm is headed by press magnate Sally Aw Sian, who succeeded her father, the "Tiger Balm" tycoon Aw Boon Haw died in 1954. He made a fortune frnm the popular Asian ointment.
The ICAC said it had uncovered a scheme involving deliberate excess print runs apparently sold to a bogus bulk distributor, but in fact a surplus sold as waste paper.
"ICAC inquiries also indicated that more recently the deliberately printed surplus and systematic disposal has ranged from 14,000 up to 23,000 copies per day."
It alleged that since at least early 1994, the circulation figures of the Hong Kong Standard and Sunday Standard newspapers "have been fraudulently and systematically inflated."
The ICAC, a graft-busting agency founded in 1974, said its officers acted on search warrants at the company's office and at the homes of some current and former staff.
The arrested six comprised three serving and one former senior employee and one former and one serving circulation supervisor.
Hong Kong's population of 6.4 million has 54 Chinese-language newspapers, about one third of them daily.
The major English-language dailies besides the Standard are The South China Morning Post, another metropolitan paper, and the regional-circulating Asian Wall Street Journal.
According to estimates published by Merrill Lynch in February, South China Morning Post has a market circulation of 104,000, while Sing Tao had 73,000.
It did not give a figure for The Hong Kong Standard, but one media analyst said he estimated the newspaper's circulation at about 40,000.
